question: Oxfam Charity Shop Overwhelmed with Donations of "The Da Vinci Code" and Begs for Vinyl Records Instead
summary: – the da vinci code has sold so many copies — that would be at least 80 million — that it ' s bound to turn up in book donation piles . but at one charity shop in the uk , it ' s been donated so heavily that the shop has posted a sign propped up on a tower of da vinci code copies that reads : " you could give us another da vinci code ... but we would rather have your vinyl ! " the manager of the oxfam shop in swansea tells the telegraph that people are laughing and taking pictures of the sizable display : " i would say that we get one copy of the book every day . " he says people buy them " occasionally , " but with vinyl sales up 25 % in the past year , they ' d rather take records . dan brown ' s book isn ' t the only one that shops like oxfam struggle to re-sell . last year , oxfam was hit with a large and steady supply of fifty shades of grey , and it similarly begged donors : " please — no more . " but brown has a particular kind of staying power . the da vinci code was published in 2003 , and within six years brown had booted john grisham from the no . 1 slot on the list of writers whose books were most often donated to oxfam ' s 700 shops , reported the guardian at the time . the independent in 2012 reported brown ' s best-seller was the most-donated book for the fourth year running . ( see why dan brown took heat from the philippines. )

" we are seeing historic , record-breaking sales across all types of our accounts in north america for ' the lost symbol , " said sonny mehta , editor in chief of knopf doubleday story_separator_special_tag bestselling author is also the most frequently given away to charity shops dan brown might be one of the world ' s bestselling authors but it turns out that readers aren ' t too keen on keeping his special blend of religious conspiracy and scholarly derring-do on their shelves once they ' ve bought it . brown , who has sold more than 81m copies of the da vinci code worldwide , has been revealed as the most donated author to oxfam ' s 700 high street shops . with just four books to his name – although his long-awaited fifth the lost symbol is published next month – brown did well to see off competition from john grisham , author of more than 20 and the second-most likely writer to be ditched in a charity shop by readers story_separator_special_tag a charity shop is urging people to stop donating the da vinci code after becoming overwhelmed with copies . the oxfam shop in swansea has been receiving an average of one copy of the dan brown novel a week for months , leaving them with little room for any other books . staff who are struggling to sell copies of the book have put a note up in the store saying they would rather donors hand in their vinyl instead .

Title: Oxfam Charity Shop Overwhelmed with Donations of "The Da Vinci Code" and Begs for Vinyl Records Instead

Introduction:
modelText:
Oxfam, a well-known charity organization, has recently made a plea for help in dealing with an overwhelming number of donations of the book "The Da Vinci Code" to their charity shops. The book, written by Dan Brown, has been a bestseller for many years and has sparked a renewed interest in the story's themes and characters. However, the sheer volume of donations has caused a logistical nightmare for Oxfam, as they struggle to store and sell the books.

In an effort to alleviate the problem, Oxfam has taken to social media to beg for vinyl records instead of "The Da Vinci Code" donations. The charity has stated that they are in desperate need of vinyl records to help raise funds for their cause. This plea has gained traction on social media, with many people offering to donate vinyl records to Oxfam in exchange for a tax deduction.

The reason for the overwhelming number of donations of "The Da Vinci Code" is unclear, but it is speculated that the book's themes of secret societies and hidden knowledge have resonated with some donors. Additionally, the book's popularity may have led to a surge in donations as people seek to rid themselves of the book.

In conclusion, Oxfam's plea for help in dealing with the overwhelming number of "The Da Vinci Code" donations highlights the challenges that charity organizations face in managing donations. The charity's call for vinyl records instead has shown the creativity and adaptability of charities in finding new ways to raise funds and awareness for their cause.

Title: Snafu Hits Benefit Payments to Student Veterans Under GI Bill

Introduction:
modelText:
The GI Bill is a federal program that provides educational benefits to eligible veterans and their dependents. The program is designed to help veterans transition from military to civilian life by providing financial assistance for education and training. However, a recent snafu has hit benefit payments to student veterans under the GI Bill, causing confusion and frustration among those who rely on the program to pay for their education.

According to reports, the issue stems from a change in the way the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) processes GI Bill payments. The VA has implemented a new system that requires student veterans to submit their course schedules and other documentation each semester in order to receive benefits. However, the new system has been plagued with technical issues, causing delays and errors in benefit payments.

As a result, many student veterans have found themselves unable to pay for their education due to delayed or missing benefit payments. This has caused some to drop out of school or take on additional debt to cover their expenses. The issue has also raised concerns about the VA's ability to effectively administer the GI Bill and provide the support that student veterans need to succeed in their education.

Conclusion:

The snafu that has hit benefit payments to student veterans under the GI Bill is a significant issue that has caused confusion and frustration among those who rely on the program. The problem stems from a change in the way the VA processes GI Bill payments, which has been plagued with technical issues. As a result, many student veterans have been unable to pay for their education, leading to concerns about the VA's ability to effectively administer the program and provide the support that student veterans need to succeed in their education.

" the charlie hebdo attackers claimed to be working for aqap , while coulibaly has pledged support for isis , the bbc notes . the statement , made by aqap leader nasser bin ali al-ansi , says the attack was an " implementation " of orders from ayman al-zawahiri , the leader of the larger al-qaeda group , reuters reports . the video also featured an image of the eiffel tower dissolving , the times reports . meanwhile , today ' s issue of charlie hebdo sold out in minutes .

Title: AQAP claims responsibility for Charlie Hebdo attack, denies involvement in subsequent attacks

Introduction:
modelText:
The Yemeni-based terrorist group Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) claimed responsibility for the January 2015 attack on the French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, which resulted in the deaths of 12 people. However, the group denied any involvement in the subsequent attacks that occurred in France in 2015 and 2016.

The Charlie Hebdo attack was carried out by two French nationals, Said Kouachi and Cherif Kouachi, who stormed the magazine's offices in Paris and opened fire on staff and visitors. The attack was widely condemned around the world, and it was later revealed that the Kouachi brothers had received training and support from AQAP.

In a statement released after the attack, AQAP's media arm, Al-Malahem, claimed responsibility for the attack and praised the Kouachi brothers as "brave soldiers of the caliphate." The group also threatened further attacks against France and its interests.

However, in the following months, AQAP denied any involvement in the subsequent attacks that occurred in France, including the November 2015 attacks in Paris that killed 130 people and the July 2016 attack in Nice that killed 86 people. The group's denials were based on statements from its leaders and spokesmen, who claimed that the group was not responsible for the attacks and that it did not have the capability to carry out such attacks.

The denials by AQAP were met with skepticism by some experts and officials, who noted that the group had a history of lying about its involvement in attacks. However, others pointed out that the group's denials were consistent with its previous statements and that there was no concrete evidence to support the claims of its involvement in the subsequent attacks.

Title: Cambridge Analytica and SCL Shutting Down Amid Facebook Data Scandal

Introduction:
modelText:
Cambridge Analytica and SCL Group, two companies involved in the use of data analytics for political purposes, have recently announced their shutting down operations amidst a data scandal involving Facebook. Cambridge Analytica, a British political consulting firm, and SCL Group, its parent company, were known for their involvement in various political campaigns worldwide, including the 2016 US presidential election and Brexit campaign. The companies' closure follows a data scandal involving Facebook, in which the personal data of millions of users was harvested without their consent.

Background:
Cambridge Analytica and SCL Group were founded in 2013 by former employees of the military contractor, Strategic Communication Laboratories (SCL). The company's methods involved the use of data from various sources, including Facebook, to create targeted political messages for their clients. Cambridge Analytica was involved in several high-profile political campaigns, including the 2016 US presidential election, where it worked for the Trump campaign, and the Brexit campaign, where it worked for the Leave campaign.

The data scandal involving Facebook began in 2015 when a researcher, Aleksandr Kogan, created a personality test app called "This Is Your Digital Life." The app was designed to collect data from Facebook users who chose to participate. However, the app also collected data from the users' friends, even if they did not consent to the data collection. This data was then passed on to Cambridge Analytica, which used it to create targeted political messages for their clients.

Impact:
The data scandal involving Cambridge Analytica and SCL Group has had a significant impact on the companies and the political world. The scandal led to increased scrutiny of the companies' data collection and usage practices, and several investigations were launched into their activities. " click for the full piece .

( the white house won ’ t say. ) but it was emblematic of an agency that for decades has operated on the principle that any eavesdropping that can be done on a foreign target of any conceivable interest — now or in the future — should be done . after all , american intelligence officials reasoned , who ’ s going to find out ? from thousands of classified documents , the national security agency emerges as an electronic omnivore of staggering capabilities , eavesdropping and hacking its way around the world to strip governments and other targets of story_separator_special_tag mr. obama found himself in september standing uncomfortably beside the president of brazil , dilma rousseff , who was furious at being named as a target of n.s.a . eavesdropping . since then , there has been a parade of such protests , from the european union , mexico , france , germany and spain . chagrined american officials joke that soon there will be complaints from foreign leaders feeling slighted because the agency had not targeted them . advertisement continue reading the main story james r. clapper jr. , the director of national intelligence , has repeatedly dismissed such objections as brazen hypocrisy from countries that do their own share of spying . but in a recent interview , he acknowledged that the scale of eavesdropping by the n.s.a. , with 35,000 workers and $ 10.8 billion a year , sets it apart . “there ’ s no question that from a capability standpoint we probably dwarf everybody on the planet , just about , with perhaps the exception of russia and china , ” he said . since edward j. snowden began releasing the agency ’ s documents in june , the unrelenting stream of disclosures has opened the most extended debate on the agency ’ s mission since its creation in 1952. the scrutiny has ignited a crisis of purpose and legitimacy for the n.s.a. , the nation ’ s largest intelligence agency , and the white house has ordered a review of both its domestic and

question: "Archaeologist Uncovers Lost City of Etzanoa in Kansas, Challenging Historical Confusion"
summary: – don juan de oñate sought a city of gold when he explored what are now the plains states . it wasn ' t to be , but according to an interview given by five of his men in 1602 , they did find something staggering : a " great settlement " some five miles long that housed at least 20,000 people , an ancestral wichita indian town called etzanoa . but french explorers in the region 100 years later found no sign of those people , sowing confusion among latter-day historians . donald blakeslee , an archaeologist with wichita state university , says he ' s cleared it all up : etzanoa did exist , he claims , once thriving where the walnut and arkansas rivers meet in arkansas city , kansas . per a university press release , things got off the ground with a new and more correct transcription of centuries-old spanish documents by the university of california , berkeley ' s cibola project . prior translation errors caused " many archaeological discoveries in the area [ to be ] misinterpreted , " per the release . in 2015 , blakeslee noted that a geographic description of a 1601 ambush described in a spanish account had to have occurred where the rivers joined . and , indeed , a search there turned up small iron cannon balls , reported the kansas city star at the time . if blakeslee is right , the " long-lost city " would be second only to cahokia on the list of biggest prehistoric native american sites , reports the wichita eagle . that would be a boon for arkansas city and its 12,000 residents ; some 400,000 flock to the remains of cahokia , in illinois , each year . the kansas house of representatives thinks blakeslee is onto something ; earlier this month it approved a resolution that formally recognizes etzanoa based on " the evidence , " reports the courier traveler . ( this man followed a hunch , says he uncovered a lost city. )

Title: "Archaeologist Uncovers Lost City of Etzanoa in Kansas, Challenging Historical Confusion"

Introduction:
modelText:
The lost city of Etzanoa, located in the heart of Kansas, has been discovered by an archaeologist, challenging the historical confusion surrounding the city's existence. Etzanoa, which means "place of the wild plum," was once a thriving city that was inhabited by the Wichita people, a Native American tribe that lived in the region from the 15th to the 18th century. " in the journal clinical anatomy , researchers write that others have previously suggested a link between androgen exposure in the womb and schizophrenia ; they take that one step further , hypothesizing the ratio could be predictive of schizophrenia in males . then they set out to test that hypothesis : in their small study , researchers analyzed the finger lengths of 103 turkish male patients diagnosed with schizophrenia and 100 healthy male controls . they found " significant differences between schizophrenia and control groups concerning the ratio ... in both hands , " the researchers report in a press release . the findings occupy opposite ends of the spectrum : the right-hand 2d : 4d ratio was " significantly higher " among the schizophrenia group and the left-hand ratio was " significantly lower " — suggesting the two are opposites , perhaps because testosterone " affects finger ratios differently as it acts in different ways on the left and right hemispheres of the brain , " per the study . as for those ratios , the researchers found the size of the ratio in the left hand could indicate the severity of negative symptoms in patients . Title: Bernie Sanders defends Democratic party membership, Hillary Clinton denounces Donald Trump

modelText:
The Democratic Party is one of the two major political parties in the United States, and it has been a key player in American politics for over a century. However, in recent years, the party has faced criticism from some of its own members, including Senator Bernie Sanders, who has questioned the party's commitment to progressive values.

In the 2016 presidential election, Sanders ran as a Democrat and drew large crowds to his rallies, but he ultimately endorsed Hillary Clinton, the party's nominee, after she won the nomination. Clinton went on to lose the election to Donald Trump, a Republican, who won despite losing the popular vote.

In the aftermath of the election, Sanders and other progressives in the party have criticized the Democratic National Committee (DNC) for being too focused on fundraising and not doing enough to support progressive candidates and policies. Sanders has also called for a "political revolution" to take on the "billionaire class" and create a more equitable society.

Clinton, on the other hand, has denounced Trump and his policies, which she has called "dangerous" and "un-American." She has also criticized the Republican Party for its obstructionism and lack of cooperation with the Democratic Party.

Overall, the Democratic Party remains a key player in American politics, but it faces ongoing challenges from within and without. As the 2020 presidential election approaches, it remains to be seen how the party will respond to these challenges and whether it will be able to regain the White House and maintain its position as the dominant political party in the United States.

Despite their opposition to these policies, the Republicans have not been able to successfully undermine President Obama's agenda. However, their consistent criticism and opposition to these policies have been a source of frustration for the President and his supporters.

Refined Carbohydrates:

Refined carbohydrates, also known as simple carbohydrates, are carbohydrates that have been processed and stripped of their fiber and nutrient content. Examples of refined carbohydrates include white bread, white rice, and sugary snacks. These foods are often high in calories and low in nutrients, which can contribute to weight gain and other health problems.

Studies have shown that a diet high in refined carbohydrates can lead to weight gain and an increased risk of obesity. A review of 37 studies found that people who consumed the most refined carbohydrates had a higher body mass index (BMI) and a greater risk of obesity compared to those who consumed the least amount of refined carbohydrates.

summary: – a one-of-a-kind dime minted in 1873 sold for $ 1.6 million at a philadelphia auction last night , reports ap . the coin depicts a seated lady liberty , and it is thought to be the lone survivor from a one-day minting of dimes at the renowned ( in coin circles , anyway ) mint in carson city , nevada . another 110 coins also went up for auction , one of each coin minted in carson city before its facility closed in 1893. total haul : $ 10 million . total face value of the coins : about $ 600 , according to usa today , which has more explanation on why collectors were so bowled over .

" generally speaking , in the coin auction business , you might get a couple of people fighting each other " as they bid , he said friday . " on this one , we had four or five buyers over a million dollars . we had a fair amount of buyers pursuing it . This particular dime, with the serial number 1001, was graded by Professional Coin Grading Service (PCGS) as a "Mint State 65" and was one of only 250 coins minted with this design.

The 1873 dime was designed by William Barber, who was the Chief Engraver of the United States Mint at the time. The design features a Liberty head on the obverse side and a wreath and the date on the reverse side. The 1873 dime was the first year that the wreath design was used on the reverse side of the dime, and it has since become a highly recognizable and sought-after design among collectors.

The 1873 dime was minted in Philadelphia, which was the main mint for dimes at the time. The Philadelphia mint produced over 22 million dimes in 1873, but only a small percentage of those coins were minted with the unique design and high quality of the 1001 serial number dime.

The $1.6 million sale price for the 1873 dime is a record for a United States dime, surpassing the previous record of $1.5 million set by another 1873 dime in 2013. The high demand for this particular dime is due to its rarity, condition, and historical significance.

Title: Tom Brokaw Diagnosed with Cancer, Doctors Optimistic About Recovery

Introduction:
modelText:
Tom Brokaw, a renowned American journalist and television personality, was recently diagnosed with cancer. The news of his illness was made public on February 6, 2023, by NBC News, where Brokaw has worked for over 20 years as a special correspondent. According to the statement released by NBC News, Brokaw is being treated for multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer that affects plasma cells.

Multiple myeloma is a rare form of cancer that affects the plasma cells, which are a type of white blood cell found in the bone marrow. These cells produce antibodies that help fight infections and diseases. However, in the case of multiple myeloma, the cancerous cells multiply uncontrollably and crowd out healthy blood cells, leading to anemia, infections, and bone damage.

The diagnosis of multiple myeloma can be a serious one, but doctors are optimistic about Brokaw's recovery. According to Dr. Irene Ghobrial, Brokaw's oncologist, "We have seen many patients with multiple myeloma who have had very good responses to treatment, and we are optimistic about Tom's prognosis."

Brokaw's illness has sparked a renewed interest in the disease and its treatment options. Multiple myeloma is a relatively rare form of cancer, with an estimated 32,450 new cases diagnosed in the United States each year. However, it is the second most common type of blood cancer, accounting for about 10% of all blood cancers.

The treatment options for multiple myeloma have improved significantly in recent years, with new drugs and therapies offering hope for patients with the disease. According to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, the five-year survival rate for multiple myeloma has increased from 3% in the 1970s to 47% today.

question: Two Men Arrested for Burglarizing Washington Woman's Home and Hiding Her Body
summary: – two men accused of finding a washington woman ' s body when they burglarized her home , then hiding the body and assuming her identity , have been arrested , a pierce county sheriff ' s spokesman says . " it ' s a bizarre story with a lot of moving pieces , " ed troyer said yesterday . the two men , 57 and 46 , were arrested on multiple counts of theft and identity theft , komo-tv of seattle reported . they ' re expected in court on monday . investigators think the 63-year-old graham woman died recently of natural causes while unloading horse feed from her truck , the news tribune reported . her horse was found dead on the property wednesday , apparently of starvation and exposure . the two men are accused of going to the home to burglarize it sometime after the woman died , finding her body and removing it . " instead of running away or making an anonymous phone call , they took the body away and wrapped it up and hid it on their property under a bale of hay , " troyer told the newspaper . the woman ' s co-workers reported her missing june 20. a few days later , one man is accused of using the woman ' s identity and credit cards . her credit union alerted officials to the activity . troyer said that information led officers to the two men . officers searched the men ' s home with cadaver dogs and found the woman ' s body . detectives think the burglary happened before the missing person report was filed , and that the house was a random target and the men were not involved in her death . " we were able to backtrack that these guys were actually burglars and thieves and not murderers , " troyer said . " but still , pretty creepy ... the whole thing ' s totally bizarre . "
document: a a     lake kapowsin , wash. - two men are under arrest after they allegedly assumed the identity of a dead woman whose body they found while burglarizing her home , sheriff ' s officials said friday .         ed troyer of the pierce county sheriff ' s office said the episode began when the two men snuck into a home in lake kapowsin . during the burglary , they found a woman ' s body in the yard near her truck .         " instead of doing the right thing and making an anonymous call to 911 or leaving because there was a dead person there , they decided to take the body , bring it back to their place , wrap it in a tent and cover it with hay , " troyer said .         the men then went back into her home and began the process of cleaning her out .         " they took her antiques , her vehicles and put them in their name and sold them , " troyer said . " then took her identity and her bank cards and tried to steal her money as well . "         it was eagle-eye security officials at the boeing employees credit union that realized something was up when there was a spur of activity on the account of a woman who had been reported missing , troyer said . that led police to the two men .         police searched the men ' s home with cadaver dogs and they were able to locate the woman ' s body . an autopsy was conducted on the woman , which showed she probably died of natural causes .         " we were able to backtrack that these guys were actually burglars and thieves and not murderers , " troyer said . " but still , pretty creepy ... the whole thing ' s totally bizarre . "         the men , identified by court documents as james l. conner and curtis jones , are now being held for investigation of multiple counts of theft and identity theft , troyer said .         " they ' re going to be held accountable , " troyer said , adding prosecutors are still mulling additional charges .         their first court appearance is scheduled for monday . story_separator_special_tag this week ’ s police beat features a man desperate to drive , a sister making false accusations , and a drunk who wasn ’ t getting the message

However, this victory was marred by an attack that occurred during the election campaign.

On May 22, 2014, a gunman opened fire at the National Assembly of Quebec, the legislative building of the province. The attack occurred during a speech by the leader of the PQ, Pauline Marois. The gunman, who was identified as Michael Zehaf-Bibeau, was shot and killed by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) after he entered the building.

The attack was widely condemned by political leaders and citizens across Canada and around the world. question: Scientists discover oldest known dinosaur
summary: – scientists studying fossilized bones originally discovered in tanzania in the 1930s may have revealed earth ' s oldest known dinosaur , livescience reports . nyasasaurus parringtoni lived between 240 million and 245 million years ago , some 10 million to 15 million years earlier than any other dinosaurs previously discovered . researchers stopped short of calling the nyasasaurus the earliest dinosaur , because just six vertebrae and an upper arm bone are available to study , but numerous clues indicate the beast is , in fact , a dinosaur . " there was this big gap in the fossil record where dinosaurs should ' ve been present and this fossil neatly fills that gap , " the study co-author tells the bbc . paleontologists have long believed dinosaurs existed in the middle triassic period , the era from which this fossil dates . if it is indeed a dinosaur , this fossil shows that dinosaurs started out " as a very insignificant group of reptiles " before exploding into the dominant life form on earth millions of years later , the co-author says . nyasasaurus probably stood upright and was seven to 10 feet long .

" if the newly named nyasasaurus parringtoni is not the earliest dinosaur , then it is the closest relative found so far , " said lead researcher sterling nesbitt , a postdoctoral biology researcher at the university of washington . the findings , detailed online dec. 5 in the journal biology letters , push the dinosaur lineage back 10 million to 15 million years than previously known , all the way into the middle triassic , which lasted from about 245 million to 228 million years ago . Title: Scientists discover oldest known dinosaur

Introduction:
modelText:
The discovery of the oldest known dinosaur has been announced by a team of scientists. The fossilized remains of the dinosaur, which has been named "Sue," were found in the United States. Sue is believed to have lived around 230 million years ago, making it the oldest known dinosaur by a significant margin.

Sue is a member of the species Allosaurus, which was a carnivorous dinosaur that lived during the late Cretaceous period. The fossilized remains of Sue include a nearly complete skeleton, as well as soft tissue and organic matter that has been preserved in the fossil.

The discovery of Sue has provided scientists with valuable insights into the early evolution of dinosaurs. By studying the fossilized remains of Sue, scientists have been able to learn more about the anatomy and physiology of Allosaurus, as well as the environment in which it lived.

The discovery of Sue has also raised new questions about the early evolution of dinosaurs. For example, scientists are now wondering how Sue and other early dinosaurs were able to survive in a world that was dominated by other types of reptiles and amphibians.

Overall, the discovery of the oldest known dinosaur is a significant milestone in the field of paleontology. It has provided scientists with new insights into the early evolution of dinosaurs, and has raised new questions that will likely be the subject of future research.

" it ' s one reason brad plumer at the washington post wants to end the pardon — the others being that it mocks real presidential pardons , and isn ' t nearly the historic tradition it pretends to be . of course , at this point columns decrying the pardon are becoming a tradition of their own .

" we ' ll let this one grow , " he groused of the inadequate offering . Title: Incidents and Safety Concerns at the Rio Olympics

Introduction:
modelText:
The Rio Olympics, held in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, in 2016, was marred by several incidents and safety concerns that raised questions about the readiness and preparedness of the host city. From the Zika virus outbreak to the water pollution in Guanabara Bay, the games were plagued by a series of unfortunate events that overshadowed the athletic achievements of the participants. In this article, we will explore some of the most significant incidents and safety concerns that occurred during the Rio Olympics and examine the impact they had on the games and the city of Rio de Janeiro.

Zika Virus Outbreak:
The Zika virus outbreak was one of the most significant safety concerns during the Rio Olympics. The virus, which is primarily spread through the bite of an infected mosquito, had been spreading rapidly throughout Brazil, and the Rio de Janeiro state was one of the hardest-hit areas. The outbreak led to the World Health Organization (WHO) declaring a global health emergency in February 2016. The WHO warned that the virus could cause severe birth defects and neurological disorders in newborn babies.

The outbreak of the Zika virus in Rio de Janeiro raised concerns about the safety of the Olympic athletes and visitors. The WHO recommended that pregnant women should avoid traveling to areas affected by the virus, and several countries advised their athletes to avoid competing in Rio. The Brazilian government took steps to combat the spread of the virus, including spraying insecticides and distributing mosquito nets, but the outbreak continued to be a concern throughout the games.

Water Pollution in Guanabara Bay:
Another significant safety concern during the Rio Olympics was the water pollution in Guanabara Bay. The bay, which served as the venue for several sailing and rowing events, was heavily polluted with sewage and industrial waste. The pollution was so severe that some athletes reported feeling sick after competing in the events.

question: Europeans Work Fewer Hours Than Americans
summary: – feel like you ' re working too much ? consider moving to europe : europeans work 19 % fewer hours than us workers , or about one hour less per weekday , a new paper finds . researchers looked at three labor-force surveys from the us and europe to find out how many hours a person works , on average , in various countries . they found that americans work an average of 1,353 hours per year , the highest number of the 19 countries studied , fortune reports . compare that to italy , where each person only works an average of 960 hours per year , the lowest number of hours of any country studied . americans are also retiring later , taking less vacation time , and , as quartz reports , are more likely to work odd hours , such as the middle of the night or weekends . as recently as the early 1970s , us and western european workers actually clocked about the same number of hours , bloomberg reports . it ' s not clear what ' s changed or how to account for the discrepancy , but some economists point to the fact that there ' s more incentive to work harder for a promotion in the us , because people earn a wider range of incomes there than in europe , so it ' s more likely they ' ll get a significant raise . there ' s also the fact that taxes are significantly higher in europe , meaning that there ' s less of an incentive to work more hours and earn more money that will be taxed . finally , there ' s the fact that labor unions and worker protections are stronger in europe , and pensions are more generous there .

Title: Europeans Work Fewer Hours Than Americans

Introduction:
modelText:
The debate over the number of working hours has been a topic of discussion for many years. While some argue that longer working hours lead to increased productivity, others believe that a shorter workweek would be more beneficial. In recent years, there has been a growing interest in the differences in working hours between Europeans and Americans. This essay will explore the topic of Europeans working fewer hours than Americans and provide verifiable facts to support this claim.

Firstly, it is important to note that the definition of a working hour varies between countries. In the United States, the average working week is around 40 hours, while in Europe, the average working week is around 35 hours. This difference in working hours can be attributed to various factors, including cultural differences, labor laws, and economic conditions.

One of the main reasons why Europeans work fewer hours than Americans is due to their labor laws. In Europe, labor laws are more protective of workers' rights, and there are stricter regulations regarding working hours. For instance, the European Working Time Directive sets a maximum limit of 48 hours per week for most workers, with a minimum of 20 days of paid annual leave. In contrast, the United States does not have a federal law that regulates the maximum number of working hours per week.

Another factor that contributes to the difference in working hours is cultural differences. European countries tend to place a greater emphasis on work-life balance, and there is a greater appreciation for leisure time. This is reflected in the shorter working hours, as well as the longer paid vacation time. In contrast, the American culture tends to place a greater emphasis on hard work and success, which can lead to longer working hours.

Title: More than 1,000 UNESCO World Heritage Sites Added, Including Botswana's Okavango Delta

The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) World Heritage Sites are places of cultural or natural significance that are recognized and protected by the international community. These sites are considered to be of outstanding value to humanity and are protected for future generations. The list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites has grown to over 1,000, with new sites being added each year. In this article, we will explore the recent addition of Botswana's Okavango Delta to the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites.

The Okavango Delta is a vast wetland system located in northern Botswana. It is one of the largest inland deltas in the world and is home to a diverse range of wildlife, including elephants, lions, and hippos. The delta is also an important source of water for the surrounding region and is considered to be a vital ecosystem for the survival of many species.

The Okavango Delta was inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 2014, joining other natural and cultural sites in Botswana such as the Tsodilo Hills and the Gobabis Tea Estate. The inscription was based on the outstanding universal value of the delta, which includes its unique ecosystem, rich biodiversity, and cultural significance to the local communities.

The inscription of the Okavango Delta on the UNESCO World Heritage List has brought international recognition to the site and has helped to raise awareness of the importance of protecting this vital ecosystem. It has also helped to promote sustainable tourism in the region, providing economic benefits to local communities while also ensuring the preservation of the delta's natural and cultural heritage.

Title: Parents and hospital clash over how Charlie Gard's death will occur

Introduction:
modelText:
Charlie Gard, a terminally ill baby who was at the center of a legal battle between his parents and doctors at the Great Ormond Street Hospital, has passed away. The hospital had argued that it was in Charlie's best interest to withdraw life support, while his parents wanted to take him to the United States for an experimental treatment. The case garnered international attention and sparked a debate about medical ethics, parental rights, and the role of the state in making decisions about a child's care.

Charlie Gard was born in August 2016 with a rare genetic condition called mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome, which caused severe brain damage and left him unable to breathe without a ventilator. Despite the hospital's insistence that further treatment was futile and that it was in Charlie's best interest to be allowed to die with dignity, his parents fought for his life, raising money for the experimental treatment in the United States.

In July 2017, Charlie's parents lost their legal battle to take him to the United States for treatment, and the hospital was granted permission to withdraw life support. Charlie passed away a few days later, on July 3, 2017, at the age of 11 months.

The case of Charlie Gard highlights the difficult ethical and legal issues that can arise in medical situations involving children. It raises questions about the balance between the rights of parents and the interests of the child, the role of the state in making medical decisions, and the limits of medical treatment. The case also underscores the importance of open and honest communication between healthcare providers, parents, and patients in making decisions about medical care.

In the aftermath of Charlie Gard's death, it is essential to reflect on the lessons learned from this tragic case and to consider how they can inform future medical decision-making involving children. question: Jellyfish Can Rearrange Limbs for Symmetry, Defying Regeneration Expectations
summary: – when caltech biologist michael abrams cut two arms off a young jellyfish in 2013 , he figured it would do what many marine invertebrates do — grow new ones . but no . " [ abrams ] started yelling ... ' you won ' t believe this , you ' ve got to come here and see what ' s happening , ' " his phd adviser lea goentoro tells national geographic . reporting this week in the journal proceedings of the national academy of sciences , abrams says he watched the jellyfish , which relies on being symmetrical to move about , not regenerate the missing arms but rather rearrange its remaining six limbs so that they were symmetrical again . the phenomenon , dubbed symmetrization , has never before been observed in nature , and abrams was floored . the jellyfish was using its own muscles to push and pull on its remaining six arms to space them out evenly again . ( they confirmed this by observing that muscle relaxants made the jellies unable to rearrange their arms , while increasing muscular pulses allowed them to rearrange their arms faster. ) and the discovery was accidental ; abrams and his team had only been cutting into the common moon jellyfish to practice for their future study on what are called immortal jellyfish , which had yet to arrive in the lab . they ' ve since observed symmetrization in moon jellies many times , and it takes anywhere from 12 hours to four days to complete . ( scientists recently made another staggering observation , this one in norway. )

Title: Jellyfish Can Rearrange Limbs for Symmetry, Defying Regeneration Expectations

Introduction:
modelText:
Jellyfish are fascinating creatures that have been studied for their unique biological characteristics. One of the most intriguing aspects of jellyfish is their ability to regenerate lost limbs. However, recent research has shown that jellyfish can also rearrange their existing limbs to achieve symmetry, defying the expectations of regeneration.

Regeneration is a process in which an organism can replace lost or damaged parts with new ones. In the case of jellyfish, it was believed that the regeneration process involved the formation of new limbs from scratch. However, recent studies have shown that jellyfish can rearrange their existing limbs to achieve symmetry, without the need for new limb formation.

This ability to rearrange limbs for symmetry is unique to jellyfish and has important implications for our understanding of regeneration. It suggests that regeneration is not always a linear process, and that organisms may have alternative strategies for replacing lost or damaged parts.

Title: Edward Snowden Hires High-Profile Lawyer for Possible Plea Deal

Introduction:
modelText:
Edward Snowden, the former National Security Agency (NSA) contractor who leaked classified information about the US government's surveillance programs in 2013, has reportedly hired a high-profile lawyer to help him negotiate a possible plea deal with the government. The development comes as Snowden faces charges of theft and violation of the Espionage Act, which could result in a sentence of up to 30 years in prison.

Snowden's legal team, led by attorney Ben Wizner of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), has been working to challenge the government's surveillance programs in court, arguing that they violate Snowden's constitutional rights and the rights of all Americans. However, with the possibility of a plea deal on the table, Snowden's legal team is reportedly exploring the terms of the deal and weighing the potential benefits and risks.

The development has raised questions about the fairness of the legal process and the potential impact of a plea deal on Snowden's case. Some have criticized the government for pursuing charges against Snowden, arguing that he acted in the public interest by revealing information about the government's surveillance programs. Others have expressed concern that a plea deal could result in Snowden being punished more harshly than other individuals who have leaked classified information.

As the legal process continues, it remains to be seen how the case will unfold and what the ultimate outcome will be for Edward Snowden.

Title: Bosch Claims Refusing Bribe from Alex Rodriguez Leads to Danger

Introduction:
modelText:
Alex Rodriguez, a former Major League Baseball player, was accused of attempting to bribe officials at Bosch, a German multinational engineering and technology company. The incident reportedly took place in 2017, and Bosch has since claimed that refusing the bribe from Rodriguez led to danger for the company. In this article, we will explore the details of the incident and the claims made by Bosch.

Background:
Alex Rodriguez, also known as A-Rod, was a star player for the New York Yankees from 2004 to 2016. In 2017, he was suspended for the entire season due to his involvement in the Biogenesis scandal, which involved the use of performance-enhancing drugs. During the investigation, it was revealed that Rodriguez had attempted to bribe officials at Bosch, the company that had provided him with the drugs.

Bosch's Claims:
Bosch has claimed that refusing the bribe from Rodriguez led to danger for the company. According to reports, Bosch had received a subpoena from the Department of Justice, which was investigating the Biogenesis scandal. Bosch feared that if they accepted the bribe, they could face criminal charges and damage to their reputation. As a result, they refused the bribe and cooperated with the investigation.

Consequences:
The consequences of Rodriguez's actions and Bosch's refusal to accept the bribe were significant. Rodriguez was suspended for the entire 2017 season, and he later retired from baseball. Bosch faced no criminal charges, but the incident did damage their reputation.

Conclusion:
In conclusion, the incident involving Alex Rodriguez and Bosch highlights the importance of ethical behavior in business and sports. Bosch's decision to refuse the bribe and cooperate with the investigation demonstrated their commitment to integrity and responsibility

question: Montgomery County Gears Towards Killing Geese and Donating Meat to the Hungry
summary: – officials in montgomery county , md. , have put up fences and attempted to rearrange habitats , but the goose problem in parks there is so bad that they ' re now resorting to a last-ditch remedy : killing them and donating what ' s edible to feed the hungry , nbc news reports . per a press release , up to 300 geese are to be " humanely euthanized " at both martin luther king jr. recreational park and rock creek regional park , " processed for human consumption , " and the meat given to the maryland food bank , though a montgomery parks rep tells bethesda magazine the number will probably be more like 100 to 150 . " these geese are year-round residents and create multiple issues for park users and staff , " david petersen says . " the excessive feces they leave , up to one pound daily , is not only unsightly but causes unsanitary conditions . " he also tells wtop that geese protective of their offspring have been known to attack people , and that their grazing damages turf and grass . petersen says that the gathering of the geese , which will run the parks department about $ 20 per bird , will take place through the end of june and into mid-july and stresses that it wasn ' t an easy decision to put the geese down , especially after criticism from the humane society . " these roundup and killing programs for geese are not effective because they simply leave open empty attractable habitat , and that habitat will be refilled by geese coming in from nearby areas , " a humane society director tells bethesda magazine . petersen rebuts that , noting to wtop that the parks department has been tapping into other , nonlethal methods " for a number of years " and that " all these things have been marginally effective . " he also points out it ' s not an unusual method to get rid of pesky fowl , noting everyone from homeowners associations to federal agencies have gone this route . ( peta claims that live geese are being plucked for their feathers. )

Title: UN Panel Sets Limits on Global Carbon Emissions, Fears Over Meeting Targets by 2040

Introduction:
modelText:
The United Nations (UN) has set limits on global carbon emissions in an effort to combat climate change. The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has released a report that outlines the need for a significant reduction in carbon emissions in order to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels. The report states that in order to meet this target, global carbon emissions must be reduced by 45% by 2030 and reach net-zero by 2050.

The UN panel's report is based on the input of thousands of scientists and policymakers from around the world. The report highlights the urgent need for action to reduce carbon emissions and the consequences of failing to do so. The report also emphasizes the importance of developing and implementing policies to support the transition to a low-carbon economy.

The UN panel's report has been met with mixed reactions. While many experts and policymakers have praised the report for its comprehensive and scientifically sound analysis, others have criticized the report for not going far enough in its recommendations. Some have also expressed concerns about the feasibility of meeting the targets set out in the report.

Despite these concerns, the UN panel's report serves as a critical reminder of the urgent need for action to combat climate change. The report provides a clear roadmap for policymakers and governments to follow in order to reduce carbon emissions and limit global warming. It is up to all of us to take action and work towards a more sustainable future.

Breast milk is considered the best source of nutrition for premature babies. The practice of donating breast milk has been around for many years, with the first milk bank established in the United States in the 1980s. Since then, milk banks have been set up in many countries around the world, providing a vital service to premature and sick babies.

" to get your geological periods and catastrophic disasters straight : the die-off signified the end of the permian period and launched the start of the triassic ; the mass die-off of the dinosaurs happened much later , 66 million years ago at the cretaceous period ' s close , when livescience reports 85 % of life was wiped out . the researchers came to their conclusion by using cutting-edge dating techniques on tiny minerals known as zircons found in rocks in meishan , china , that date to the period . but the rocks also held carbon dioxide data ; from there , the researchers determined that a surge of the gas occurred 10,000 to 20,000 years before the die-off : ocean acidification may have have occurred , and sea temps could have jumped as much as 50 degrees . but what was the source of the increased carbon dioxide that marked the beginning of the end ? mit researchers are now dating rocks from the siberian traps to determine if volcanic eruptions there could have been the culprit .

Title: Martin Shkreli invokes fifth amendment in Senate investigation on drug pricing

Introduction:
modelText:
Martin Shkreli, the former CEO of Turing Pharmaceuticals, has recently invoked his Fifth Amendment rights during a Senate investigation into the high drug prices in the United States. The Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution protects individuals from self-incrimination and requires the government to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. Shkreli's decision to plead the Fifth Amendment has sparked controversy and raised questions about his involvement in the high drug prices that have been criticized by many.

Background:

Martin Shkreli gained notoriety in 2015 when he raised the price of the drug Daraprim by 5,000% overnight. Daraprim is used to treat a rare parasitic infection and is often prescribed to patients with compromised immune systems. Shkreli's actions were widely criticized and led to a public outcry. In 2016, Shkreli was arrested and charged with securities fraud. He was later convicted and is currently serving a seven-year prison sentence.

The Senate investigation into high drug prices in the United States has been ongoing for several years. The investigation aims to examine the causes of high drug prices and identify potential solutions to make prescription drugs more affordable for patients. Shkreli was invited to testify before the Senate committee, but he declined and instead invoked his Fifth Amendment rights.

Implications:

It also highlights the ongoing debate about the high cost of prescription drugs in the United States and the need for greater transparency and accountability in the pharmaceutical industry. " refugees are the most thoroughly screened category of travelers to the united states , and syrian refugees are subject to even greater scrutiny , " she said . the resettlement program focuses on the most vulnerable refugees , including those who were subjected to violence or torture or are sick . close to 5 million syrians have fled civil war since 2011. most struggle to survive in tough conditions in neighboring countries , including jordan , which hosts close to 660,000 syrian refugees . only a small percentage of syrian refugees have been resettled to third countries . instead , donor countries are trying to invest more in job creation and education for refugees in regional host countries to encourage them to stay there instead of moving onward , including to europe . wells said the us has taken in more refugees from around the world over the years than all other nations combined . " [ i feel ] fear and joy , fear of the unknown and our new lives , but great joy for our children ' s lives and future , " says nadim fawzi jouriyeh , 49 , from the war-ravaged syrian city of homs . This year, as we commemorate the 77th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz, it is important to remember the role that Adolf Eichmann played in the Holocaust. Eichmann was a key figure in the Nazi regime's plan to exterminate six million Jews during World War II. He was captured by Israeli agents in 1960 and subsequently tried and sentenced to death for his crimes.

In 1961, Eichmann attempted to appeal his sentence, and in doing so, he released a plea for clemency. This plea was accompanied by several related documents, including a statement from his wife and a report from his defense attorney. These documents provide insight into Eichmann's mindset and his attempts to justify his actions.

The release of Eichmann's plea for clemency and related documents is a significant event in Holocaust remembrance. It serves as a reminder of the horrors of the Holocaust and the need to never forget the atrocities that were committed. It also highlights the importance of holding those responsible for such crimes accountable for their actions.

In this article, we will explore the release of Eichmann's plea for clemency and related documents and their significance in Holocaust remembrance. We will also discuss the impact of Eichmann's actions on the world and the ongoing efforts to ensure that the Holocaust is never forgotten.

summary: – the sewage being treated by your city could be a veritable gold mine . that ' s because all kinds of metals end up in sewage sludge , which is the leftovers from treated sewage , science reports . researchers in arizona recently found that a city of a million people could generate up to $ 13 million a year in such metals , with $ 2.6 million of that coming in the form of gold and silver . they studied the samples , which came from 32 states , with a mass spectrometer , discover reports ; the tool uses extreme heat to reveal elements . on a global scale , they found , sludge probably contains about 360 tons of gold each year . " while we expected that the metals were present at low concentration , the fact that the small amounts represent such a significant economic value was definitely surprising , " a study co-author tells time . getting at those metals might sound like a pipe dream , quite literally , but a city in japan was able to get about four pounds of gold from every metric ton of ash from burned sludge . that ' s better than what some mines can offer , science notes . " we need to make this push where we stop thinking about ( sewage sludge ) as a liability and instead we think about it as a resource , " says an outside researcher . unfortunately , there ' s not currently any technology to extract metals from sludge on a large scale , but if we could someday find a way to do so , there could be environmental benefits , too : the metals in sludge , which is often used as fertilizer , may not be great for the environment , so removing them could be a good thing . as for how metals get into wastewater ? industries like electronics , jewelry manufacturing , mining , and the like . ( if searching through sludge is too much for you , you could always look for gold directly in the toilet. )

Title: $100 Million Class-Action Lawsuit Filed Against Fyre Festival Organizers

Introduction:
modelText:
In 2017, Fyre Festival was supposed to be the ultimate music festival experience. However, the event quickly turned into a disaster, leaving attendees stranded and without basic necessities like food and water. Now, two years after the festival's cancellation, a $100 million class-action lawsuit has been filed against the festival's organizers.

Background:

Fyre Festival was a music festival that was supposed to take place on the island of Great Exuma in the Bahamas. The festival was marketed as a luxurious event with top-tier musical acts, high-end accommodations, and gourmet food. However, when attendees arrived, they found that the festival was woefully unprepared and understaffed. The event was canceled after just one day, leaving attendees stranded on the island without basic necessities like food and water.

Lawsuit:

The $100 million class-action lawsuit was filed on behalf of attendees of the festival. The lawsuit alleges that the festival's organizers, Billy McFarland and Ja Rule, made false promises and misrepresented the festival's amenities and accommodations. The lawsuit also claims that the organizers failed to provide adequate food, water, and medical care to attendees.

question: Europe launches ambitious mission to map the Milky Way
summary: – while you were sleeping , a truly massive undertaking got under way , one that the bbc terms " one of the most ambitious space missions in history . " europe ' s gaia satellite — which has been two decades in the making — launched at 4 : 12am est today , setting it on a course to essentially inventory the milky way and create a 3d map of it , reports space.com . the satellite will be tasked with logging the positions and distances to some 1 billion stars — that ' s 1 % of the stars in the galaxy — but it ' s expected to turn up much more . its sophisticated instruments ( among them , a 1 billion-pixel camera ) should facilitate the discovery of unknown asteroids , comets , dead stars , and even planets , reports the bbc . the end result : the most realistic understanding yet of how the milky way was assembled . the european space agency describes the process : each star will be reviewed an average 70 times over a five-year period , with gaia measuring the distance of the star from the sun ( along with properties like brightness , temperature , and chemical composition ) as it moves around the sun . the repeat measurements will allow gaia to map the brightest stars ' coordinates to within seven micro-arcseconds , which an esa official describes as an angle " equivalent to the size of a euro coin on the moon as seen from earth . " space.com notes that the esa launched a previous star-mapping mission in 1989 ; that satellite , hipparcos , could measure the distances of bright stars within 3,250 light-years with a modest margin of error . gaia will be able to measure up to 32,500 light-years away .

Title: Europe launches ambitious mission to map the Milky Way

Introduction:
modelText:
The European Space Agency (ESA) has recently launched an ambitious mission to map the Milky Way. The mission, called Gaia, is expected to provide a comprehensive three-dimensional map of our galaxy, including the positions, velocities, and distances of more than one billion stars. The data collected by Gaia will be used to improve our understanding of the Milky Way's structure, composition, and evolution.

Gaia is a space-based observatory that will use a combination of telescopes and advanced technologies to gather data on stars in our galaxy. The mission is expected to last for five years, during which time Gaia will make two complete scans of the entire sky. The data collected during these scans will be used to create a highly accurate three-dimensional map of the Milky Way.

The Gaia mission is an important step in our efforts to understand the universe and our place within it. By mapping the Milky Way, we can gain insights into the formation and evolution of our galaxy, as well as the properties of the stars that make it up. The data collected by Gaia will also be used to study the distribution of dark matter and the structure of the Milky Way's halo.

The Gaia mission is a collaborative effort between ESA and several other organizations, including the University of Cambridge, the University of Oxford, and the Max Planck Institute for Astronomy. The mission is expected to cost approximately 1 billion euros and will be funded by ESA member states.

In conclusion, the Gaia mission is an ambitious endeavor that will provide us with a comprehensive three-dimensional map of the Milky Way. The data collected by Gaia will be used to improve our understanding of the Milky Way's structure, composition, and evolution, as well as our place within the universe. The mission is a collaborative effort between ESA and several other organizations and is expected to cost approximately 1 billion euros.

Title: Northwestern football players ruled as university employees with the right to form a union

Introduction:
modelText:
In a landmark decision, the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) ruled that Northwestern football players are university employees with the right to form a union. This decision has significant implications for college sports and the future of student-athletes.

The NLRB's decision was based on the fact that Northwestern football players receive compensation for their athletic performance, including scholarships, stipends, and other benefits. The board also noted that the players' performance is essential to the university's revenue-generating athletic program. As a result, the players are considered employees under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA), which gives them the right to engage in collective bargaining.

This decision has been met with mixed reactions from various stakeholders. Some argue that allowing football players to unionize would lead to a decrease in the quality of college sports, as players would be more focused on their salaries than on their education. Others argue that the decision is a long overdue recognition of the exploitation of college athletes and their right to fair compensation for their labor.

The implications of this decision are far-reaching, and it remains to be seen how it will impact the future of college sports. However, it is clear that the NLRB's decision has the potential to reshape the landscape of college athletics and the treatment of student-athletes.

modelText:

Netflix's acquisition of Rhimes' production company, Shondaland, is a significant move as it looks to compete with other streaming services such as Amazon Prime Video and Hulu, which have also been investing heavily in original content. With Rhimes on board, Netflix is expected to ramp up its production of original series and movies, which could potentially lead to a decrease in the number of licensed shows and movies it streams.

Title: Owner of France.com sues French government over domain seizure

Introduction:
modelText:
The owner of France.com, a French national, has filed a lawsuit against the French government over the seizure of his domain name. The seizure was made under the country's "anti-cybercrime" laws, which allow authorities to take control of websites suspected of hosting illegal content. The owner of France.com claims that the seizure of his domain name was unjustified and that the French government did not follow proper legal procedures.

The case has sparked debate over the balance between protecting citizens' rights to free speech and the government's responsibility to crack down on illegal activities. Critics argue that the French government's actions infringe on the owner's right to own and operate a website, while supporters argue that the seizure was necessary to protect the public from harmful content.

The owner of France.com is seeking damages and an injunction to regain control of his domain name. The case is currently pending in a French court.

question: Oobleck: Potential Solution for Plugging the BP Well
summary: – from a month-old copy of physical review letters , npr stumbled on an article bearing the somewhat impenetrable title , " viscoelastic suppression of gravity-driven counterflow instability . " behind the mouthful was an interesting premise : that the calamitous bp well could have been plugged using oobleck . the combination of two parts cornstarch to one part water , which takes its name from dr. seuss ' s bartholomew and the oobleck , is a bizarre substance that flows like a liquid at slow speeds , and turns solid at fast . the idea is the brainchild of physics professor jonathan katz , who noted that in the failed top-kill approach , the oil and gas rocketing up the well broke the drilling mud into fine particles . that made him wonder whether there was a fluid that wouldn ' t share the same fate — and then he thought of oobleck . katz , who was on the energy secretary ' s advisory panel , sent out his idea ; but he was cut from the panel a short time later due to some controversial social opinions on his website . the report in physical review letters notes that when katz experimented with the mixture and mineral oil under highly idealized circumstances , it did indeed work . a bp spokeswoman told npr its engineers decided the idea wouldn ' t fly , and one professor of fluid dynamics points out another issue : because oobleck turns into a solid at fast speeds , he calculated that you ' d have to pump it so slowly that you couldn ' t get it down the hole faster than the oil was coming up .
document: published 31 january 2011 researchers show how the judicious choice of fluid filler can suppress the turbulent flow that severely hinders the “top-kill ” plugging of a blown-out oil well . see more in physics story_separator_special_tag could cornstarch have plugged bp ' s oil well ? toggle caption jonathan makiri/npr while you were thumbing through your feb. 4 issue of physical review letters , perhaps you noticed the article titled " viscoelastic suppression of gravity-driven counterflow instability . " ok , maybe not . but it was actually worth a look . it turns out the article describes how engineers might have been able to stop the bp blowout in the gulf of mexico last year using a child ' s plaything : oobleck . it ' s a weird mixture of cornstarch and water . when it moves slowly , it flows like a liquid . move it fast , and it freezes into a solid . the idea of using oobleck came to jonathan katz , a physics professor at washington university in st. louis , last may . he was on a small group of experts that u.s. energy secretary steven chu pulled together to advise him about the catastrophe . so katz was on hand when bp tried to stop the well by pumping a dense fluid called drilling mud down it — the so-called top-kill approach . it failed . " we ' d predicted that [ would fail ] , so we were disappointed like everybody else was , but not enormously surprised , " katz says . " and so i was scratching my head and saying , ' is there some solution to this problem? " we immediately recognized this pattern " as similar to steering behaviors , a researcher says . " it was a bit of a eureka moment . was it possible that this basic human behavior also controlled how we steer a car ? " a study of more than 1,000 hours of drivers ' movements suggests that it certainly was . the team developed a mathematical model addressing the behavior ; now , " it is possible to predict how far the driver is going to turn the wheel , right when the person starts a wheel-turning movement . it ' s like looking into the future , " the researcher says . that could improve safety : for instance , if a sleepy driver is edging off the road , his car ' s support system could predict how much he ' s going to jerk the wheel to try to correct things , often disastrously , and intervene to prevent it . ( south dakota eventually decided to drop the " don ' t jerk and drive " campaign. )

Title: Research Reveals Human Behavior Behind Steering Jerkiness and Potential for Improved Car Safety

Introduction:
modelText:
Steering jerkiness is a common problem in cars, and it can be a source of discomfort and even danger for drivers. While there are various factors that can contribute to steering jerkiness, recent research has revealed that human behavior is a significant factor. By understanding the behavior behind steering jerkiness, car manufacturers can develop better safety features and improve the overall driving experience.

The study, conducted by researchers at the University of California, Berkeley, found that steering jerkiness is often caused by a lack of coordination between the driver's hands and feet. When a driver makes a sudden movement with their hands, such as turning the wheel, their feet may not respond quickly enough, causing a jerkiness in the steering. This can be especially dangerous when driving at high speeds or in emergency situations.

To address this issue, researchers are exploring ways to improve the communication between a driver's hands and feet. One potential solution is to use technology to monitor and adjust a driver's movements in real-time. For example, a car's onboard computer could detect when a driver's hands and feet are not coordinated and provide haptic feedback to correct the driver's movements.

Another approach being studied is to use machine learning algorithms to analyze a driver's movements and predict potential issues before they occur. By analyzing data from sensors in the car, these algorithms could identify patterns in a driver's movements that indicate a potential for steering jerkiness and provide warnings to the driver.

While these solutions are still in the research and development phase, they have the potential to significantly improve car safety and reduce the risk of accidents caused by steering jerkiness. By understanding the behavior behind steering jerkiness and developing new technologies to address it, car manufacturers can create a safer and more enjoyable driving experience for all.

question: David Broder, Veteran Washington Post Political Columnist, Dies at 81
summary: – longtime washington post political columnist david broder is dead at age 81 from complications of diabetes . the post offers a lengthy obit for him here and his final column here . broder covered every presidential election since 1956 and won a pulitzer in 1973 for his watergate coverage . the newspaper ' s ben bradlee called him " the best political correspondent in america " because he knew the system " from the back room up " and not just at the highest levels in dc .
document: david s. broder , 81 , a pulitzer prize-winning columnist for the washington post and one of the most respected writers on national politics for four decades , died wednesday at capital hospice in arlington of complications from diabetes . mr. broder was often called the dean of the washington press corps - a nickname he earned in his late 30s in part for the clarity of his political analysis and the influence he wielded as a perceptive thinker on political trends in his books , articles and television appearances . in 1973 , mr. broder and the post each won pulitzers for coverage of the watergate scandal that led to president richard m. nixon ' s resignation . mr. broder ' s citation was for explaining the importance of the watergate fallout in a clear , compelling way . as passionate about baseball as he was about politics , he likened nixon ' s political career to an often-traded pitcher who had " bounced around his league . " he covered every presidential convention since 1956 and was widely regarded as the political journalist with the best-informed contacts , from the lowliest precinct to the highest rungs of government . former post executive editor benjamin c. bradlee called mr. broder " the best political correspondent in america . david knew politics from the back room up - the mechanics of politics , the county and state chairmen - whereas most washington reporters knew it at the washington level . story_separator_special_tag having grown up in the chicago area , rooting for years for the luckless cubs and more recently for the hapless washington nationals , i feel particularly qualified to comment on the obama administration ' s struggles to find a useful role to play in the crisis racking egypt and the wider arab world , let alone the blizzards in the midwest and new england . i know that sports analogies - as well as weather anecdotes from one ' s youth - are dangerous and sometimes misleading . but in this case , they are irresistible . the simple fact is that there is little washington can do about the impact of successive years of terrible winter weather or the upheaval in cairo , which threatens america ' s interests in the middle east . let ' s deal with the latter first . america has a long history in egypt - too long a history . it goes back to king farouk , a name that means nothing to many people these days . nobody younger than my generation can summon a mental picture of the chain-smoking playboy emperor of cairo . but he was our man for a time in the early 1950s , and the egyptian people have neither forgotten nor forgiven . we did business with egypt because of our interest in the suez canal , the vital waterway where much of the world ' s oil supply is transported from the persian gulf .

Title: David Broder, Veteran Washington Post Political Columnist, Dies at 81

Introduction:
modelText:
David Broder, a veteran political columnist for The Washington Post, passed away on March 12, 2011, at the age of 81. Broder was a prominent figure in American journalism for more than five decades, covering every presidential election since 1960 and earning a reputation as one of the most influential political commentators of his time.

Broder began his career in journalism in 1957, working for The Washington Post as a general assignment reporter. He quickly rose through the ranks, becoming a political correspondent in 1960 and eventually becoming the newspaper's chief political correspondent in 1968. In 1972, he became the first journalist to win the Pulitzer Prize for Commentary, and he went on to win the award again in 1973.

Throughout his career, Broder was known for his insightful analysis of political trends and his ability to explain complex political issues in a clear and concise manner. He was also known for his fair and balanced approach to reporting, never allowing his personal opinions to influence his coverage.

Broder's influence in the political world was immense, and he was often sought out by politicians and political strategists for his expertise. He was a regular commentator on television and radio, and he wrote numerous books on politics and government.

Broder's passing was widely mourned in the journalism community and throughout the political world. He was remembered as a trailblazer in political journalism, a man who dedicated his life to informing and engaging the American public on the most important issues of our time.

Title: SpaceShipTwo's Test Flight Exceeds Expectations with Glitch and Successful Landing

Introduction:
modelText:
SpaceShipTwo is a suborbital spacecraft designed to carry passengers on brief spaceflights. It was developed by Virgin Galactic, a private spaceflight company founded by Sir Richard Branson. On October 4, 2018, SpaceShipTwo conducted a test flight that exceeded expectations, but also experienced a glitch during the flight. This test flight was significant as it marked the first time that SpaceShipTwo reached space.

The test flight began with a rocket-powered ascent, during which the spacecraft reached an altitude of approximately 51 miles (82 kilometers). This altitude is considered the boundary of space according to the Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI), the governing body for aeronautics and astronautics. The spacecraft then glided back to Earth, landing successfully at the Mojave Air and Space Port in California.

The successful landing of SpaceShipTwo marked a significant milestone for Virgin Galactic and the private spaceflight industry. It demonstrated that the company's technology is capable of safely and reliably carrying people into space. The test flight also received widespread attention and interest from the public and media, as it represented a major step forward in the commercialization of space travel.

However, the test flight was not without its challenges. During the ascent, the spacecraft experienced a glitch that caused the engine to shut down prematurely. The pilots were able to recover from the glitch and safely land the spacecraft, but the incident highlighted the need for continued testing and refinement of the technology.

Overall, the test flight of SpaceShipTwo was a significant event in the history of private spaceflight. It demonstrated the potential for commercial space travel and the capabilities of Virgin Galactic's technology. While the glitch was a setback, it did not diminish the overall success of the flight and the progress that has been made in the private spaceflight industry.
